In Java, you can't store decimal numbers (such as 3.14, 12345.678, or 0.00009) in an int or long, because these types only store whole numbers (i.e., no decimals). That's why Java provides floating-point data types.
There are 2 types of floating-point data types in Java:
• float (for 32-bit decimal values i.e smaller decimal numbers)
• double (for 64-bit decimal values i.e larger, more precise decimal numbers)
Let's See It in Action

data.code:
float data type size is between 1.4E-45 to 3.4028235E38
double data type size is between 4.9E-324 to 1.7976931348623157E308


Example:
float 1212.0
double 2.13454354322E10

data.html: Note: The capital 'E' in 3.4028235E38 represents scientific notation — it's the same as writing 3.4 × 1038. It's a common way computers represent very large or very small decimal numbers.
float vs double What's the Difference?

FloatDouble
Size32 bits64 bits
PrecisionAbout 7 digitsAbout 15–16 digits
MemoryUses less memoryUses more memory
Default TypeNot default decimal typeDefault decimal type
Example UseSimple values, speedFinancial/Scientific data

Remember the f
If you're assigning a decimal to a float, don’t forget the 'f' at the end:

data.code: float price = 99.99f; // If you forget f, Java will assume it’s a double by default and show a compiler error.

data.html:
Coding Tips
Use float when memory matters and you don’t need super precision.
Use double for most decimal calculations — it’s more accurate and the default for decimals.
